results.title: The Lonely night
results.creator_credit: Mental Health Film Board, Irving Jacoby and Willard Van Dyke
results.brief_description: Dramatized story of a young woman’s journey out of the dark hours of emotional disturbance. Shows the process of psychiatric treatment candidly and completely. Caroline Cram, after a suicide attempt, seeks help from psychiatry, and learns to recognise the relationship between her past experiences and present problems. To show, for contrast, a healthy childhood environment, the Dunn family is seen at a picnic. The parents curb and soften their children’s demands and rivalries, and build their emotional strength. Narrator: Frank Silvera
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mental Health Film Board, Irving Jacoby and Willard Van Dyke

results.title: The Lonely island
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Photographed at the Australian Antarctic Research Station, Macquarie Island, the film shows the bird and sea elephant life of the island. The black browed albatross with its nine feet wing span, the royal penguin, the rock hopper penguin and the gentoo all came there in the spring to nest and rear their chicks. Sea elephants also come there to have their pups and to grow new coats. Photography: George Lowe

results.title: The Lone Ranger. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: Republic Pictures Corporation, William Witney and John English
results.brief_description: An extremely rare serial find - the first filmed story of the mysterious masked hero of the plains, starring Lee Powell and Chief Thundercloud. PLEASE NOTE: The quality of the sound and picture of this print are only fair. This is the only complete version of this serial available; the two previously missing chapters are in English with Spanish subtitles.

results.title: The Lombards at the first Crusade = I Lombardi alla prima Crociata
results.creator_credit: Gabriele Lavia, National Video Corporation, Radiotelevisione Italiana and Brian Large
results.brief_description: Giuseppe Verdi’s “I Lombardi” with libretto by Temistocle Solera, was first performed at La Scala in 1843. This made for television production, also performed at Teatro alla Scala in Milan, features the Orchestra and Chorus of La Scala conducted by Gianandrea Gavazzeni and a wonderful cast of lead singers including Jose Carreras (Oronte), Ghena Dimitrova (Giselda), Silvano Carroli (Pagano) and Carlo Bini (Arvino). The story takes place during the time of the first Crusade in 1099 A.D. in the settings of Milan, Antioch and the country near Jerusalem. Giovanni Agostinucci’s stage sets are many and varied, adding depth and substance to the production of this medieval story of Crusaders, knights and soldiers, and damsels in distress. A spectacular presentation visually, excellent support cast and an outstanding solo violin performance by Franco Fantini. Sung in Italian with no subtitles. Booklet included.

results.title: The Lollipop opera by Don Freeman
results.brief_description: A lively film about a barber who draws his own shop, adds a “Mop Top” customer, then cuts and shampoos the boy’s unmanageable hair, finally rewarding him with a lollipop for his good behaviour. Rossini’s “Barber of Seville” provides a lively musical accompaniament. No dialogue. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: The Log raft: a Norwegian summer story
results.creator_credit: Svekon Films, Karin Sandberg and Sverre Sandberg
results.brief_description: Three young children spend the summer at their island cabin at the fjords. Their love of nature makes their experience universal but their curiosity leads to some dramatic moments. A strange surreal quality film with excellent close-up photography.

results.title: The Lodger
results.creator_credit: Gainsborough Pictures, Sir Michael Balcon, Carlyle Blackwell Sr and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: While ‘The Lodger’ was not director Alfred Hitchcock’s first film, it was the first to truly deserve the designation “A Hitchcock Picture”. British matinee idol Ivor Novello plays Jonathan Drew, a quiet, secretive young man who rents a room in a London boarding house. Drew’s arrival coincides with the reign of terror orchestrated by Jack the Ripper. As the film progresses, circumstantial evidence begins to mount, pointing to Drew as the selfsame Ripper. In the original story by Mrs Belloc-Lownes, suspicions concerning Drew were confirmed; but Ivor Novello was a star of the first magnitude, and stars of the first magnitude just didn’t play murderers back in 1926. Thus, we learn at the last possible moment that Drew is innocent, and is in fact on the trail of the Ripper himself. Hitchcock makes his cameo appearance at a desk in the newsroom early in the film. Some people claim he also appears later in the crowd watching the arrest. Hitchcock wanted an ambiguous ending to the film, but the studio wouldn’t allow it to be implied that Ivor Novello might actually be the murderer.

results.title: The Locker
results.brief_description: An experimental film about a young man and his involvement with a mysterious locker. During an interview voices emerge from the locker, later its resence torments him. The situation is treated in a surrealistic manner. Cast: James Dunkley, Paul Smythe, Nancy Gabrielle

results.title: The Local handyman
results.brief_description: The life of a typical English blacksmith showing the great variety of jobs that he is called upon to undertake. The film stresses the blacksmith’s modern methods, adapted to today’s needs, and his traditional craftsman’s attitude to his work.
